awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: TRACKING PCO2, REGIONAL CLIMATE, AND VEGETATION CHANGE DURING MID-MIOCENE GLOBAL WARMING THROUGH THE EXCEPTIONAL PLANT RECORDS OF THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST, USA
awd_abstract_narration:
Seventeen million years ago, Earth's climates gradually heated up and then stayed warm for several million years. This event is termed the mid-Miocene Climatic Optimum (MMCO) and it was the last global warming event before the Ice Age. Still, what caused the warming and how it affected plants and animals remains unclear. This project uses plant fossils preserved in lake sediments in Washington, Idaho and Oregon to study how ecosystems changed during the MMCO. Specifically, the researchers will investigate whether CO2 (a greenhouse gas) emitted from Pacific Northwest (PNW) volcanoes during the mid-Miocene helped heat the atmosphere, how climate changed in the PNW, and how local plant communities adjusted to these changes. Mid-Miocene ecosystems were similar to today; therefore, learning about the MMCO helps predict what may happen to today's ecosystems experiencing climate change. Several graduate and undergraduate students are being trained, and a new display featuring MMCO research in the Burke Museum is being created. 

This project examines the causes and effects of mid-Miocene warming through the study of 18 exceptional PNW paleofloras from before, during and after the MMCO. Together, the floras form a sequence of linked data on atmospheric pCO2, regional climate change, and vegetation that can be precisely dated. The floras often preserve macrofossils, pollen, and phytoliths, providing an integrated view of local and regional climate and vegetation. Project aims are to: (1) do high-precision U-Pb geochronology on volcanic ashes at 13 floral sites across the MMCO; (2) study plant assemblages at all 18 sites to infer (a) vegetation composition, diversity, structure, and successional stage, (b) local-regional climate, and (c) atmospheric pCO2; and (3) use these data to evaluate the nature and timing of PNW ecosystem change during the MMCO. The project will contribute to a biogeographically more resolved understanding of how the Earth climate system and vegetation respond during global warming events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project used plant fossils preserved in lake sediments in Washington, Idaho and Oregon to study how ecosystems changed during the mid-Miocene Climatic Optimum (MMCO), the last global warming event before the Ice Ages. This project examined eighteen exceptional Pacific Northwest paleofloras from before, during and after the MMCO, to form a sequence of linked data on atmospheric pCO2, regional climate change, and vegetation response. A key need and outcome of this study was the application of high-precision radioisotopic dating to volcanic tephra horizons that directly bracket thirteen of these paleofloras in their stratigraphic sampling context, rather than relying upon often tenuous correlations to volcanic rocks in other basins. In several cases the dating of multiple tephras within a single locale has allowed construction of continuous Bayesian age models of the stratigraphic sections, refining the age of the floras and other proxy records within the sedimentary archive.

Using this geochronology we have for the first time fully sequenced this floral record and placed it within the regional record of Columbia River Basalt Group large igneous province volcanism, and the global framework of climate change across the MMCO. Paleoflora are now precisely tied to, for example, the very beginning (16.58 Ma Juliaetta flora) and ending (16.13 Ma lower Mascall flora) of eruption of the Grande Ronde Basalt Formation, the most voluminous and rapidly emplaced portion of the Columbia River Basalt Group. Another highlight is the construction of a new age model for the Clarkia flora of northern Idaho, among the best preserved and studied macrofloras of the Miocene. This age model precisely dates two leaf horizons and their paleo-atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration estimates to 15.90 Ma and 15.85, respectively, and in the immediate aftermath of Columbia River flood basalt eruptions. Finally we have documented the precise ages of additional macroflora and pollen records over the subsequent 1 million years within the heart of the MMCO. 

Among its broader impacts, this grant has cemented collaborations between scientists across numerous geoscience subdisciplines and professional settings, including academic scientists, museum curators, federal agency, and state geological survey scientists. The grant and studies also promoted the scientific training and career development of an undergraduate McNair scholar, several graduate students, and a National Science Foundation Postdoctoral Fellow. Aspects of the research were incorporated into an undergraduate classroom activity on the analysis of tephra, and have informed the outreach efforts at regional Idaho and Washington natural history museums. The results have also had relevance for regional mapping and mineral resource characterization by the Idaho Geological Survey.

Modified by: Mark D Schmitz
